The study of language as a cognitive phenomenon is a relatively new discipline. It originated in the late 1970s and early 1980s. Since then, cognitive linguistics has been a rapidly growing field that has both benefited from and contributed to its allied disciplines of cognitive psychology, cognitive anthropology, and cognitive neuroscience. The course begins by examining the advantages and shortcomings of the cognitive perspective on the different levels of language (e.g., sounds, words, sentences, texts, etc.). Students explore the connections of cognitive linguistics with the related fields that are broadly referred to as the "cognitive sciences." No background in linguistics is required, but interest in linguistics is expected.

CORE S144 FY.course_description: What is privacy? Why does privacy matter? Is privacy dead? Students examine these and other questions about privacy from social, legal, and technical perspectives. Students explore the history of privacy in the United States from the 1800s to the present, discussing how changing norms and technologies have influenced privacy across society. Then they focus on how the Internet, computing systems, and connected devices have enabled novel privacy vulnerabilities and protections. Finally, students learn how computer scientists study privacy and practice writing about privacy across genres. Students who successfully complete this seminar satisfy the Core Sciences requirement.  Noah Apthorpe is an assistant professor in the Department of Computer Science. His research combines human-computer interaction, networks, and machine learning to study the privacy and security implications of connected technologies, including Internet of things devices and education platforms. He teaches courses at Colgate on privacy, cybersecurity, artificial intelligence, and hardware development.

CORE S148 A.course_description: The science of writing secret messages has been studied for millennia. Code makers have kept secrets safe, aided in winning wars, and enabled secure banking transactions. Code breakers have uncovered nefarious plots, helped to win wars, and gained access to millions of people’s personal data. Students investigate the science of code making and breaking throughout the ages and how it has impacted the course of history. Topics include the early substitution ciphers, translating lost ancient languages, the role of cryptography in World War II, and modern cryptography in the age of the internet.

CORE S149 FY.course_name: FSEM: Willpower: The Science of Self Control
CORE S149 FY.course_description: Willpower allows people to delay gratification, resist temptations, and reach challenging long-term goals. Our ability to control our will influences nearly every area of our lives. This course is designed to be a unique opportunity to engage in this fascinating topic from a scientific perspective. Students begin by sharing their own experiences with trying to exert willpower. Students then explore psychological theories of self-control and read the scientific research that supports and extends these theories. As a way of deepening understanding of this literature and developing writing skills, students write and rewrite short papers that react to these readings. In addition to reading and writing about the science that supports and extends these theories, students actually do some of this science as we design, conduct and analyze data from our own study, and see, first hand, how research works. At the end of the course, students return to their own willpower experiences and analyze the motivational forces at work using the principles of psychological science.Students who successfully complete this seminar satisfy the Core Sciences requirement.  Regina Conti is an Associate Professor in the Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences. She teaches courses on human motivation, research methods and neurodiversity. She loves to engage students in the scientific process to answer questions of personal importance. Her recent research investigates the community inclusion of people with neurodevelopmental disabilities.

CORE S155 A.course_description: Examines sexuality, with an emphasis on developmental, familial, and societal factors that influence sexuality. Throughout the semester, students learn about how current understandings of sexuality came to be, focusing on historical contexts, existing research, as well as ethical and methodological concerns. Students examine content relevant to the diversity of experiences within sexuality and how sex research has shaped these experiences, for better or worse.

CORE S155 B.course_description: Examines sexuality, with an emphasis on developmental, familial, and societal factors that influence sexuality. Throughout the semester, students learn about how current understandings of sexuality came to be, focusing on historical contexts, existing research, as well as ethical and methodological concerns. Students examine content relevant to the diversity of experiences within sexuality and how sex research has shaped these experiences, for better or worse.

CORE S156 A.course_description: Drugs, used recreationally and medicinally, can have physiological and behavioral consequences that are important to both the individual and society. The processes in the brain and nervous system that mediate drug-induced effects on behavior and physiology are examined with emphasis on the strategies and methods used to evaluate, scientifically, the effects of drugs. This course is designed for students with no background in the field of neuroscience.

CORE S158 FY.course_name: FSEM: Molecules That Rock Your World
CORE S158 FY.course_description: Elements, like iron, and alloys, like bronze, have entire “ages” named after them. Students read accounts of how elements and molecules have affected the course of civilization from ancient to current times. Students may be familiar with notorious elements like uranium and plutonium and their impact on world events, but how did tin change the course of history? Moving quickly from elements to molecules, students look at some of the roles molecules have played in colonization, health, environment, lifestyle, and so forth. The emphasis is not on the history of molecules, but rather molecules in history. As students explore these interesting histories, they pull in a few of the relevant scientific observations and molecular structures that give rise to the important characteristics of particular “world rocking” molecules. Coursework is centered on outside reading and class discussion with the addition of some short basic lectures on fundamental chemistry to provide context. The plan for this fall includes Uranium (energy and weapons), Salt (food preservation and conquest), Nitrogen (food production and explosives), Water (clean drinking and infrastructure), Ethanol (from fermentation and distillation to use and abuse), and Progesterone (birth control and women's rights). Students who successfully complete this seminar satisfy the Core Sciences requirement.  Jason M. Keith is an Associate Professor of Chemistry at Colgate University. His research is based on the application of Density Functional Theory to various projects involving electronic structure, spectroscopy and mechanism. His primary research efforts focus on transition metal systems. While his research tends to focus on fundamental concepts such as bonding, applied projects in his group are more commonplace and are often related to clean energy and the environment.

CORE S162 A.course_description: Food is essential for all of us to survive but we often take food and food preparation for granted. Have you ever wondered why some food tastes as it does or how food preparation can alter the taste of consistency of a dish? What is a balanced diet and why do we strive to have one? Students explore how understanding the science of food and cooking enhances our enjoyment of it as well as our benefit from it. Students look at the history and culture of human nourishment, and explore some controversial aspects of food and food technology, such as use of additives, genetically modified organisms, and diets and weight loss programs. If you have an appetite for learning or are just food motivated, this course may appeal to your senses.

CORE S182 FY.course_description: From the beginning of history, art and technology have influenced each other. For example, during the Renaissance, Piero della Francesca, an artist-mathematician, and Leonardo da Vinci, an artist-engineer, made both scientific and artistic breakthroughs. The thread that links art and science, experiment and theory, is problem solving, which demands creativity and rigor.  This seminar introduces students to interdisciplinary thinking: they learn the elements of computer programming in the context of visual art, developing problem solving skills that bridge disciplines. Students formally analyze the visual structure of paintings to create abstractions, sketches and collages, which provide templates that structure the computer programs they write.   Through this interdisciplinary lens, students see how the principles of computer science respond naturally with other aspects of a liberal arts education, integrating today’s technology into the spirit of humanism. No prior programming experience is expected. Students who successfully complete this seminar satisfy the Core Sciences requirement.  Elodie Fourquet is an Assistant Professor in Computer Science with research expertise in Computer Graphics and Visual Perception. In both research and teaching the interdisciplinary aspect of the Computer Science field is key to her approach.

CORE S188 FY.course_description: Dogs are a fascinating study organism. From their very beginnings their evolutionary history contains unpredicted effects across all levels of biological organization. From the social construct of being a wild animal (wolf), to becoming dependent on man (domestication), and colonizing our homes and our beds (inter-species bonding). The history of this single species provides a rich learning opportunity to introductory biology students. Course readings and discussions include an exploration of most branches of biology, in an inter-disciplinary manner: evolution, ecology, genetics, physiology, and behavior, with the constant of exploring how dogs are unique to each of those branches in biology. Emphasis is on the interaction between wild animals and early humans, and tracks that interaction through time as the domestication of the dog has progressed. Further exploration includes physiological aspects of canine biology that are beneficial for humans, for example, cancer research. Students are challenged to formulate questions about science and how science relates to the inter-species relationship we have created with “man’s best friend.” Students who successfully complete this seminar satisfy the Core Sciences requirement.  Professor Ana Jimenez is an animal physiologist interested in why small dog breeds live significantly longer than large breeds.

CORE S192 FY.course_description: Temperatures are increasing, sea levels are rising, many species are on the move, and some have gone extinct. These changes in Earth’s environments profoundly shape our lives, influencing where we live, the food we eat, the work we do, and how we see ourselves and others. Geologists have proposed that we live in a new interval in the history of our planet, the Anthropocene, in which the activities of our species have transformed Earth systems in ways that will leave an indelible signature in the geologic record. How do we know that these environmental changes are underway and that humans are responsible? Students explore the scientific evidence for the Anthropocene, considering how Earth systems operate both with and without us. Students learn about the process of science by critically reading the scientific literature, by collecting, analyzing, and interpreting scientific data, by communicating scientific research to different audiences, and by considering the social context in which science is done. Students who successfully complete this seminar satisfy the Core Sciences requirement.  Assistant Professor Paul Harnik is a paleontologist who studies the impacts of past and present environmental change on marine biodiversity, and specifically the capacities of species to adapt and move in response to climate change and their vulnerabilities to extinction. Outside of work, Paul loves reading fiction, making photographs, and exploring the woods with his family. Paul is excited to explore global environmental change together and to support you on your academic journey at Colgate and beyond.

CORE S194 FY.course_description: Since the early civilizations, events resulting from electric charges have inspired human minds. Various early civilizations created fascinating stories associated with natural events such as lightning and northern lights as they thought of those events as a result of supernatural interventions. However, the development of modern scientific methods in the 16th and 17th centuries spurred major discoveries in 18th and 19th centuries which allowed humanity to understand and control charge carrying particles called electrons. With this newfound ability, humans created light without fire, were able to send long-distance messages in the blink of an eye, and developed computing devices. Within a span of about two hundred years after the first modern inventions associated with electrons, human civilization has completely been transformed. Through this course structured around lectures, discussions, demonstrations, readings, and research assignments, students learn about the human endeavor to understand electrons and how that understanding has shaped our civilization. Following the historical timeline of major discoveries associated with electricity & magnetism, students learn about the process of scientific discoveries and the development of electronics through the stories of individuals behind major discoveries in the context of contemporary sociocultural structures. Furthermore, the students learn about the ongoing socioeconomic, geopolitical, and environmental impact of electronics beyond the consumer market and get to contemplate the future of electronics and hence, the future of human civilization. Students who successfully complete this seminar satisfy the Core Sciences requirement.  Professor Ramesh Adhikari studies charge transport in organic and biomaterials and is interested in developing “green” electronics. Currently, he is working on developing electronic devices based on leaves and aromatic amino acids.

CORE S197 FY.course_name: FSEM: Ethics, Algorithms, and Artificial Intelligence
CORE S197 FY.course_description: The rapid development of AI tools raises a host of moral questions that we are currently ill-equipped to answer. For example, if an algorithm decides whether to give you a job, a loan, or parole, what does it take for that decision to be fair? How should autonomous vehicles be designed to behave in life-or-death situations? What guardrails are needed for human-machine relationships? How can we ensure that advanced AI won’t have catastrophic consequences? As corporations, think-tanks, and governments begin to give answers in the form of laws and codes of ethics, our job as consumers and citizens is to understand what causes these questions to arise, and why they matter, so we can make informed choices. This course brings together recent work in AI ethics from philosophy, computer science, and law, to help students expand their knowledge of these issues. Students who successfully complete this seminar satisfy the Core Sciences requirement.  Aaron Wolf teaches in the Department of Philosophy and the Core Sciences program, and writes on topics at the intersection of morality and logic. He's been at Colgate since 2015, and is passionate about helping students develop their own research projects.

COSC 215 A.course_description: No robust code can be written without employing the quintessential skills of software analysis and testing. Moreover, these skills are required by the profession, both as a software developer and tester. Coursework is designed to move our students’ knowledge, understanding and practical skills from haphazard software testing and limited code analysis towards learning about and meeting the real world standards. It both teaches established methods of software analysis and testing, and how to apply them to real world software.

COSC 215L A.course_description: A weekly two-hour laboratory that focuses on the analysis, design and implementation of automated testing of real world software. Required corequisite to COSC 215.

COSC 255L B.course_name: Gadgets and Gizmos: the Hardware/Software Interface Lab
COSC 255L B.course_description: Required corequisite for COSC 255. Students work collaboratively to build embedded systems and practice implementing course concepts.

COSC 311 A.course_description: A survey of influential topics in computer security and privacy with an emphasis on how they affect individuals and societies. Security topics include applied cryptography, identity management, network security, website security, operating systems security, and side channel attacks. Privacy topics include web tracking, anonymous browsing, database (de)anonymization, mobile and IoT data collection, contextual integrity, useable privacy, and privacy regulation. Students learn technical details of security and privacy vulnerabilities and defenses, practice programming and testing computer systems to detect and prevent vulnerabilities, and discuss the influence of human behavior and societal factors on security and privacy.

COSC 311L A.course_description: Discussion-based laboratory and required corequisite to COSC 311: Security, Privacy, and Society. Students read contemporary accounts of security and privacy incidents, prepare discussion questions, and engage in debates about the technical and societal factors underlying these case studies.

COSC 311L B.course_description: Discussion-based laboratory and required corequisite to COSC 311: Security, Privacy, and Society. Students read contemporary accounts of security and privacy incidents, prepare discussion questions, and engage in debates about the technical and societal factors underlying these case studies.

COSC 426 A.course_description: Language is an amazing and intricate human capacity and building computational systems that process human language (Natural Language Processing; NLP) has widespread applications: both practical (e.g., searching the internet, virtual assistants, chatbots, autocorrect, translation systems, audio captioning, and hate speech detectors) and scientific (e.g., as models of the human mind). Coursework has three interrelated goals. First, to develop the language and tools necessary for understanding, building, and evaluating NLP systems. Second, to engage in the scientific process by reading papers, replicating existing results, developing research questions and running experiments to answer these questions. Third, to critically examine the broader impact of NLP systems on society.

COSC 426 B.course_description: Language is an amazing and intricate human capacity and building computational systems that process human language (Natural Language Processing; NLP) has widespread applications: both practical (e.g., searching the internet, virtual assistants, chatbots, autocorrect, translation systems, audio captioning, and hate speech detectors) and scientific (e.g., as models of the human mind). Coursework has three interrelated goals. First, to develop the language and tools necessary for understanding, building, and evaluating NLP systems. Second, to engage in the scientific process by reading papers, replicating existing results, developing research questions and running experiments to answer these questions. Third, to critically examine the broader impact of NLP systems on society.

ECON 236 A.course_description: Although athletics have played an important cultural, religious, and martial role in societies throughout history, the commercialization of sports is a much more recent phenomenon. Students apply economic theory and empirical methodology to the analysis of sports in order to examine the interactions between sports and economics, including the institutions that organize sports and the unique economic data made available by sporting contests. The specific fields of economics covered include industrial organization, public finance, labor economics, and game theory. Special consideration is also given to discussions of the economics of collegiate and amateur sports.

ECON 236 B.course_description: Although athletics have played an important cultural, religious, and martial role in societies throughout history, the commercialization of sports is a much more recent phenomenon. Students apply economic theory and empirical methodology to the analysis of sports in order to examine the interactions between sports and economics, including the institutions that organize sports and the unique economic data made available by sporting contests. The specific fields of economics covered include industrial organization, public finance, labor economics, and game theory. Special consideration is also given to discussions of the economics of collegiate and amateur sports.

EDUC 101 FY.course_description: Provides an introductory exploration of issues concerning the educational system. It is designed for students to gain a critical perspective of the purpose and functions of the American school while at the same time drawing contrast and comparison to educational systems around the world. Embedded within this main theme, students investigate the historical foundations of education, socio-cultural influence upon academic achievement (e.g., gender, sexuality, race, economic status, ability), and educational policy decisions that play a major role in students' educational attainment and opportunity. Course materials support a variety of pedagogical methods. Students are encouraged to connect class readings and discussions to their personal schooling experiences, which allows students to acquire fresh and innovative perspectives on their educational foundations. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the social relations, institutions, and agents areas of inquiry requirement or the confronting collective challenges liberal arts practice requirement.   John D. Palmer is a Professor of Educational Studies where he teaches social and cultural foundations of education. Beyond Colgate University, he is on the board of two nonprofits that serve recently resettled refugees in the Syracuse area -- The Boaz Foundation (educational services) and Building the Bridge Foundation (housing assistance) and serves as a deacon at the Korean Church of Syracuse where he is active with local missionary endeavors.

EDUC 321 A.course_description: Studies psychological theories and research on learning and teaching, and examines how these are applied and practiced within contemporary education processes and institutions. In particular, students examine topics such as learner differences and labels, learner identity, moral development, motivation, behavior, theories of intelligence and assessment. Students learn about the historical and contemporary practice of educational psychology as a scientific discipline, and examine its role in contemporary understandings of disability, race, gender, and sexuality. In addition to engaging with dominant theories and research on learning and teaching, students critically examine the role of psychological expertise in the classroom and within schooling, and look to situate that expertise within broader social justice frameworks. Teacher candidates are required to complete school-based fieldwork hours in conjunction with this course.

ENGL 156 FY.course_description: A study of Caribbean literature and society post-independence, tracing the conflicts and contradictions inherent in the post-colonial experience. The texts students analyze show the Caribbean as a complex society still caught up in its self-definition. As it contends with the afterlives of Empire, Caribbean society negotiates identity through discourses of race, class, gender, and sexuality. Students explore Caribbean literature, film, music, art, and ritual, placing special emphasis on the following themes: migration and diaspora; globalization and violence; music and revolution; religion and other politics. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the human thought and expression areas of inquiry requirement or the confronting collective challenges liberal arts practice requirement.  Kezia Page is associate professor of English and Africana and Latin American Studies. Her current work explores surveillance in Caribbean literature and culture. Prof. Page is from Kingston, Jamaica. She lives in Hamilton with her family.

ENGL 205 FY.course_description: Although focused on the literature and music of the 1920s, this course is less about what F. Scott Fitzgerald dubbed “the Jazz Age” than it is the American inscription of race in the Modernist era. Our growing distance from that clamorous time makes it increasingly possible for us to recognize the transformative power of our own gaze upon it. Students consider how ways of reading and interpreting inform (and so inevitably transform) what we read and interpret. Students proceed as did many of the figures on our syllabus: by crossing the boundaries between discourses, arts, and semiotic systems. Nevertheless, students interrogate Fitzgerald’s famous phrase and examine the different resonance it held for writers and poets, playwrights and musicians—black and white, male and female, popular and elite. This era set in motion socio-cultural changes that are still very much in motion and students consider how its arts might help us better understand ourselves. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the human thought and expression areas of inquiry requirement, or the artistic practice and interpretation liberal arts practice, or the confronting collective challenges liberal arts practice requirement.  Professor of English, Michael Coyle, is founding President of the Modernist Studies Association, Past President of the International T.S. Eliot Society and recipient of its Lifetime Service Award, and has served on the advisory board of the National Poetry Foundation. He writes about modern poets like T.S. Eliot, Mina Loy, Langston Hughes, and Ezra Pound, and modernist cultural productions ranging from the formation of popular culture itself to jazz, radio, the martini cocktail, and discourses of race after the First World War.

ENGL 208 FY.course_name: FSEM: Sex and the Global City
ENGL 208 FY.course_description: An introduction to literary study using the relationship between sexuality, literature and the history of global cities as a jumping off point for considering the problems, practices, and possibilities of literary study. Students undertake close reading of modern texts to discover how urban settings influence our understandings of racial and ethnic identity, gender roles, sexuality, and multiple forms of sexual relationships. Coursework also addresses the ways that the cosmopolitan city provides new forms and content for both modern identities and post-modern narratives. Works of literature are contextualized by a variety of critical and historical works from the modernist and post-modernist periods. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the human thought and expression areas of inquiry requirement or the artistic practice and interpretation liberal arts practice requirement.  Professor Nimanthi Rajasingham teaches literatures from the global south, such as South Asia, Africa, the Caribbean and the Middle-East, and Immigrant fictions from the US, UK and Canada. My teaching also uses critical race and feminist studies methodologies.

ENGL 221 A.course_description: An examination of English novels in which the evocation of place is central to meaning. Students will consider both the means by which authors represent place and the implications of that representation. Texts will include Horace Walpole's The Castle of Otranto, Virginia Woolf's Mrs. Dalloway, George Gissing's The Nether World, and Thomas Hardy's Tess of the d'Urbervilles. Throughout the term there will be a focus on the way authors create an imaginative geography based in the physical world but not identical to it.

ENGL 306 A.course_description: A study of American literature in the context of society and culture in the United States from 1830 to the end of the Civil War in 1865, with special emphasis on the impact of the anti-slavery, utopian, and women's rights movements. The diverse readings include works by Frederick Douglass, Ralph Waldo Emerson, Fanny Fern, Margaret Fuller, Nathaniel Hawthorne, Harriet Jacobs, Herman Melville, Harriet Beecher Stowe, Henry Thoreau, and Walt Whitman.

ENGL 441 A.course_description: A study of several of the author's major works, including Ulysses.

ENST 309 Y.course_description: Led by the faculty director of Colgate's study abroad program to the University of Wollongong, offered each fall semester by the program in Environmental Studies and the Department of Geography. Australia's unique characteristics and history provide a rich setting for the interdisciplinary study of topics in environmental studies and geography. Through class lectures and discussion, critical reading, independent research papers, and field trips, students consider a broad range of historical and contemporary human-environment relationships. A series of field excursions planned and led by the faculty director allow students to experience Australia’s rich and diverse flora and fauna, its environmental and cultural heritage, and illustrate environmental policy challenges for 21st-century Australia.

FMST 224 AX.course_description: An introduction to major works of Italian cinema from the silent era to contemporary productions. Students will watch and discuss groundbreaking films by Italian directors such as Rossellini, Fellini, Antonioni, Pasolini, Wertmüller, Benigni, and others. Places Italian cinema within the context of European art cinema and film theory, and focuses on the ways these films represent and challenge Italian history, culture, and identity. It emphasizes the study of cinematic analysis and filmmaking techniques, as well as the historical and cultural situation in Italy from the 1920s to the present. Students are required to attend weekly screenings in addition to regular class meetings. Taught in English, with the option of a discussion group in Italian.

FMST 364 A.course_name: Desiring Machines: AI and Race in Contemporary Media
FMST 364 A.course_description:
What distinguishes human beings from machines? Can a machine become human? Artificial intelligence is a cross-disciplinary field that seeks to imagine and develop machines able to reproduce, automate, and exceed the cognitive and sensorial capabilities of biological organisms.
Throughout the 20th and 21st centuries, our understanding of these machines has served as a cipher for what it means to be human, and, more so, for who counts as human and who does not. Depictions of AI in movies and video games draw on long histories of racialization that frame
particular populations as more or less human, more or less expendable, and more or less deserving of rights, opportunities, and ownership of their own bodies. Students in this course will trace the conceptual genealogies of AI, and investigate how our collective representations of AI
illuminate and contribute to the production of race in contemporary America. Course texts will be drawn from diverse media including film, video games, literature, and generative AI such as ChatGPT. Course assignments will include speculative design projects that ask students to engage with course concepts, objects and questions via the media of their choice (e.g. visual art, coding, creative writing, performance, etc.). No prior familiarity with AI or computation is necessary.

FMST 371 AX.course_description: Focuses on the ways that comics - often defined as the interplay of words and images - convey specific messages, whether instructional, narrative, persuasive, or other. Close analyses draw on principles of visual rhetoric, comics scholarship, photography, and related disciplines. Readings cover the theory, history, terminology, and genres of graphic narratives.

FMST 390 B1.course_name: Special Topics in Film and Media Studies: Playful Polemics: Videogame Theory, History and Methods
FMST 390 B1.course_description:
Fall 2024
Provides an introduction to the interdisciplinary study of video games. Each week, students play one or more assigned games and complete readings drawn from a variety of fields including media studies, race, gender and sexuality studies, and computer science. Through this approach, students develop a sophisticated critical vocabulary that allows them to analyze the formal and genre characteristics of video games, how they reflect and engage with contemporary sociopolitical concerns, and how they have circulated globally and historically. Course assignments include a series of short exercises with different modes of writing and creative practice, a midterm analysis of the formal and genre features of the game of your choice, and a final group research project where students may choose to engage via practice-based making or “traditional” textual analysis. All levels of experience with gaming, theory, and computation are welcome and encouraged (even if any of this is brand new, just bring your excitement and willingness to try new things).

Students are required to sign up for one section of the lab (wherein we will play games together in the new state-of-the-art Gaming Lab).

FMST 390 B2.course_name: Special Topics in Film and Media Studies: Playful Polemics: Videogame Theory, History and Methods
FMST 390 B2.course_description:
Fall 2024
Provides an introduction to the interdisciplinary study of video games. Each week, students play one or more assigned games and complete readings drawn from a variety of fields including media studies, race, gender and sexuality studies, and computer science. Through this approach, students develop a sophisticated critical vocabulary that allows them to analyze the formal and genre characteristics of video games, how they reflect and engage with contemporary sociopolitical concerns, and how they have circulated globally and historically. Course assignments include a series of short exercises with different modes of writing and creative practice, a midterm analysis of the formal and genre features of the game of your choice, and a final group research project where students may choose to engage via practice-based making or “traditional” textual analysis. All levels of experience with gaming, theory, and computation are welcome and encouraged (even if any of this is brand new, just bring your excitement and willingness to try new things).

Students are required to sign up for one section of the lab (wherein we will play games together in the new state-of-the-art Gaming Lab).

FREN 121 FY.course_name: FSEM: Introduction to French Language & Culture I
FREN 121 FY.course_description: With 321 million Francophones, French is the fifth most spoken language in the world. This course is intended as an introduction to French Language, Literature and Culture. The primary goals of this course are two-fold: 1) To help you develop the four major skills of reading, listening, speaking, and writing. Real-life culturally appropriate themes and contexts are presented for student engagement individually and in small groups. By the end of the course, students should be able to understand and express themselves comfortably in French with common daily situations. 2) Students come to  understand the broader interconnections between language and culture, especially in the Francophone regions of the world. Through simple readings and music, the course lends itself to a more nuanced appreciation of the French language and culture. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the human thought and expression area of inquiry or the language study liberal arts practice requirement.  Mahadevi Ramakrishnan has been a faculty member of the Romance Languages Department at Colgate University for over 17 years. Aside from her passion for languages in general, she is keenly interested in studying the interplay of French language and culture particularly on the French Caribbean islands of Martinique and Guadeloupe.

FREN 222 FY.course_description: How do we come to be who we are? How do we tell our own stories? What can we learn from each other? What does it mean to be a human community? These are some of the questions this course invites students to consider as they discover texts written by various prominent authors from West and North Africa. The product of a complex history, this is a literature where cultures, identities, genres, and languages intersect. It gives voice to rich questions of identity and self-definition through the exploration of traditional as well as innovative forms of writing. Together, students engage in close reading of these texts and have broader discussions on themes and concepts such as imperialism and colonialism, post-colonialism, cultural translocation, gender, race, sexuality, religion, and multilingualism. In doing so, students encounter new ways of reflecting on questions and issues that concern us all, our self-definition, and the way we relate to others. This course is taught in English but should especially be of interest to students with some experience with the French language or in French-speaking countries. For interested students with some experience in French, there may be the opportunity of a separate optional “Culture and Languages Across the Curriculum” component. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the Human Thought and Expression area of inquiry requirement, or the artistic practice and interpretation liberal arts practice, or the confronting collective challenges liberal arts practice requirement.  Hélène M. Julien is professor of French and Women’s, Gender and Sexuality Studies. With a specific focus on contemporary French literature and literature from North Africa and its diaspora, her research explores the ways in which personal and collective selves find their voices in relation to history, memory, gender, race, sexuality, and culture.

FREN 434 A.course_name: Storytelling: Medieval and Early Modern Short Stories
FREN 434 A.course_description: Why do people tell stories? What do these stories reveal about a culture? This seminar investigates the development of the short story in France. Beginning with its inception in the vernacular tradition in Old French, the course traces the evolution of short narrative fiction from its varied origins in medieval literature to its codification into a new genre, the nouvelle, in the most famous story collections of the Renaissance. Special emphasis will be placed on the specificity of each work within its cultural and historical context in order to understand how stories reflect and comment on the societies for which they are composed. In addition to exploring the social, religious, and intellectual traditions of the Middle Ages and Renaissance reflected in these stories, the course also examines questions of audience and authorship, the ways in which short fiction differs from longer narrative works, and manuscript studies. Students read authors such as Marie de France, Jean Bodel, Jacobus de Voragine, Marguerite de Navarre, and the work of critics such as Paul Zumthor, Hans-Robert Jauss, and Jacques Derrida.

FREN 482 A.course_name: Major French Authors: From Plague to Covid: Epidemics in Contemporary Literature in French
FREN 482 A.course_description:
Spring 2024 Focus:
Tales of epidemics, real or fictitious, have long occupied the literary imagination. From Camus' iconic La Peste to the first literary works in French about the Covid-19 pandemic, from Ionesco's absurdist Rhinocéros to Tadjo's polyvocal novel on the most recent ebola epidemic in Western Africa, students focus on some of the major literary texts of the 20th and 21st centuries that focus on deadly epidemics. Students consider how tales of epidemics can serve as metaphors for the spread of toxic ideologies and societal illnesses, as well as pathways to understanding human and social attitudes that lead to them; how storytelling can serve as a tool to engage with the traumatic realities of an epidemic and its after-effects; what the role of literature may be in the face of an extraordinary historical event that has the potential to radically alter human lives.

GEOG 105 FY.course_description: Climate change is the defining environmental and social issue of our time. That people are causing global warming is the overwhelming consensus in the scientific community. Challenges linked to it, such as coastal flooding, heat stress, and declining crop yields, are already affecting millions of people. But while the basic mechanisms are well understood, and the global community increasingly appreciates the consequences of a warmer world, the issue is controversial. Students analyze why people disagree about climate change. Students explore the causes, consequences, and possible response options. People can live the good life, and address climate change. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the social relations, institutions, and agents areas of inquiry requirement or the confronting collective challenges liberal arts practice requirement.   Peter Klepeis, Professor of Geography, studies people and the environment. Recent projects investigate invasive species in Australia, religious-based protection of forests in Ethiopia, and the environmental history of Patagonia.

GEOL 110 FY.course_description: Central New York has changed dramatically throughout geologic time. A billion years ago, the area around Colgate was underneath a mountain belt the size of the Himalayas; 400 million years ago, the area was in the tropics and covered by a shallow sea. And as recently as 20,000 years ago, an ice sheet a mile thick covered Hamilton. How can we possibly know these things? The evidence is actually in the landscape all around us; we just need to learn how to read the clues left behind. And what better way to learn about these events than to be outside! This unique field-based seminar is designed to use the area around Colgate as a natural laboratory to study the geologic history of the region. The highlight of the course is Monday afternoon field trips to local areas where students learn first-hand how to observe and interpret evidence for these and other dramatic geologic changes. Therefore, if you enroll in this seminar, you should plan to keep your Tuesday afternoons free from 1:20 to 5:00 PM. Evaluation are based on semi-weekly writing assignments and a final research project on the geologic history of New York. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the Natural Sciences & Mathematics area of inquiry requirement or the Quantitative & Algorithmic Reasoning liberal arts practice requirement.  Martin Wong is in the Department of Earth and Environmental Geosciences and has taught at Colgate since 2005. Martin researches how and why tectonic events such as mountain building and continental rifting occur, mainly in the western U.S.

GEOL 303 A.course_description: Explores the fundamental chemical principles that govern how our planet came to be what it is today. In particular, focus is on how to use chemistry as a tool to understand major geological processes, from the formation of the planet to processes that are particularly important to environmental quality, and thus to humans.

GPEH 253 AX.course_description: Colonial states often justified their rule through a reference to the “civilizing mission,” a central part of which was the provision of ‘modern’ health care and education. But what truly was the role of these programs in the exploitative colonial system? And how did they set the stage for global health programs, all the way to the present? Through an examination of the field of global health in the 19th and 20th century, this course explores the history of global health from its roots in colonial medicine to contemporary responses to Ebola. Using historical sources, it focuses on the social, political, economic histories of global health, discussing the relationship between public health interventions and violence, racial discrimination, and caretaking and empathy.

GPEH 309 A.course_description:
Pharmaceutical research, production and distribution as well as accompanying scientific, legal and business models across the globe are an incredibly rich sight for a multifaceted and interdisciplinary intellectual engagement with ethics, scientific innovation and equity and equality as central themes. Thinking about bodily integrity, voluntary and informed consent and access and lack of it to healthcare resources, juxtaposed with marketing and corporate oriented economic models of pharmaceutical companies opens up space for critically assessing the trajectory of scientific research as it trickles down to consumerist medical practices. Further, contextualizing contemporary practices of pharmaceutical research and distribution through diverse ethnographic accounts allows for a deep understanding of a layered relationship between data and humans in the context of medical knowledge and practice. Concretely, this form of a critical assessment of contemporary pharmaceutical practices asks the following: In what ways
do the global networks of knowledge production and ideas surrounding ethical research shape, and are shaped by, the locally specific understandings of legal and medical ethics of care? How do the innovative and changing pharmaceutical landscapes inform the ways in which humans understand their own bodily and medical realities and identities?

HIST 101 A.course_name: The Growth of National States in Europe
HIST 101 A.course_description: Examines national states after 1450; conflict in Europe and world-wide commercial and colonial ambitions; Renaissance culture, the Protestant revolt, Spanish ascendancy; 17th-century French absolutism and constitutional government in England; Austria, the weakened Germanies, the rise of Prussia and Russia; 18th-century liberalism; and the French Revolution, Napoleonic conquest, and the European settlement of 1815.

HIST 108 AX.course_description:
An introduction to major political and social transformations across the Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries of the Americas, covering the period from 1800 to the present. Students build foundational knowledge on movements for independence, postcolonial struggles for sovereignty,
efforts at national building, and revolutions and political violence. Students learn about major figures from throughout the region from Benito Juárez to Che Guevara and Rigoberta Menchú. Coursework equally emphasizes the experiences of ordinary people, particularly members of marginalized groups such as Indigenous communities, Afro-Latin Americans, rural peasants, and the urban poor. Class time combines interactive lectures with discussions of historical texts by Latin American actors in translation, with graded assignments including exams and analyses of primary sources. Students successfully completing the course are well-positioned for further academic study of Latin American topics across departments and for travel, work, and/or research in the region.

HIST 120 FY.course_description: Museums are not only sites of culture and heritage, they are also hubs for community-building. In addition, museums increasingly serve as economic engines. In the United States, museums contribute more than $50 billion to the economy each year, and they support more than 726,000 jobs. Students are introduced to the interdisciplinary array of historical, theoretical, and practical topics that comprise the fast-growing field of Museum Studies. Key themes include: the history and function of museums; the ethics of collecting and museology; the theory and practice of exhibition and object display; the role of power and politics in museum spaces; the potential of museums to serve as sites of conflict mediation; and the practical aspects and challenges of museum management, education, and curating. In addition to classroom-based instruction, students make site visits to several area museums, both on- and off-campus. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the social relations, institutions, & agents area of inquiry requirement or the confronting collective challenges liberal arts practice requirement.  Alexander Karn is Associate Professor of History and the University Professor for First-Year Seminars. He serves on the Advisory Board of Colgate's program in Museum Studies, and he is the convener of the Historical Dialogues, Justice, and Memory Network. His research and teaching focus on the politics of history in contemporary societies and the use of historical dialogue as a tool for promoting justice and reconciliation.

HIST 241 FY.course_name: FSEM: Life and Death in Early Modern Britain
HIST 241 FY.course_description: Big personalities and names dominate popular consciousness of early modern Great Britain: Henry VIII; Mary, Queen of Scots; Elizabeth; Oliver Cromwell. We can acknowledge the importance of such figures, however, without crowding out other, less prominent stories that are crucial for understanding this tumultuous period in British History. Britain underwent major political and religious changes between the late fifteenth and early eighteenth centuries, from the English and Scottish Reformations to the formation of the British state in 1707 from what had been the independent kingdoms of England and Scotland. Yet, these were far more than just high political developments. They had significant, and often hugely disruptive and traumatic effects on people’s lives and communities, and on how people saw themselves in the world. Nonetheless, life went on, in ways that can seem both alien and surprisingly familiar—and students use the myriad historical sources for this period, including diaries, newspapers, government records, and visual art, to do the imaginative and analytic work to understand how regular people experienced everyday life and major historical developments. In doing so, students also gain insight into the deep historical roots of modern social and political issues such as Brexit and the status of Northern Ireland. Students who successfully complete this seminar satisfy the social relations, institutions, and agents area of inquiry requirement.  Tristan Tomlinson is senior lecturer in University Studies and History. He specializes in the histories of early modern Britain and its empire, and is particularly interested in issues of health, population, and interconnections throughout the British Atlantic World.

HIST 253 AX.course_description: Colonial states often justified their rule through a reference to the “civilizing mission,” a central part of which was the provision of ‘modern’ health care and education. But what truly was the role of these programs in the exploitative colonial system? And how did they set the stage for global health programs, all the way to the present? Through an examination of the field of global health in the 19th and 20th century, this course explores the history of global health from its roots in colonial medicine to contemporary responses to Ebola. Using historical sources, it focuses on the social, political, economic histories of global health, discussing the relationship between public health interventions and violence, racial discrimination, and caretaking and empathy.

HIST 338 A.course_name: The Age of Absolutism in Europe
HIST 338 A.course_description:
Fall 2024 Course Description
Using the development and decline of political absolutism as a frame, students examine society, politics, and culture in Europe from the late sixteenth to the late eighteenth centuries. The major political developments of this period had disruptive and traumatic effects on people’s lives and communities, and on how people saw themselves in the world, even as many aspects of everyday life showed significant continuity. Coursework covers a variety of topics, including: justifications for absolutism; alternative ideas of rights and legitimate authority; war and modern states; overseas empire and global trade; popular culture and print; and the Enlightenment.

HIST 356E AX.course_description: This two-week extended study program based in Honolulu, Hawai'i enables students to learn about the history of Hawai'i and Pacific Islander cultures through firsthand experience. Students participate in service-learning projects, learn directly from local scholars and experts, and engage with historical and archeological sites around the island of O'ahu. Research and reflection projects allow students to expand their work from HIST/NAST 356 in light of new perspectives and experiences.

HIST 389 A.course_description:
What is a reproductive technology – IVF and the pill, perhaps, or maybe the fetal monitors and
forceps, or even a DNA test? This class explores these and other technologies which made and remade ideas of biological reproduction and the family in the 20th century, highlighting histories of the Global South. Reproductive technologies are used as a lens to discuss the relationship of
technology to medicine, the processes of medicalization, health activism, the intersections of law and healthcare, and the ways in which reproductive technologies produced, expressed, or challenged concepts of gender, sexuality, and race. Rooted in the philosophy of Reproductive Justice, this course also centers the relationship between reproductive technologies and reproductive politics, and highlights the role of race and class in the history of reproductive medicine, exploring how the same technologies could be sources of personal freedom, or used as tools of violence, eugenics, imperial domination, and reproductive control.

ITAL 224 AX.course_description: An introduction to major works of Italian cinema from the silent era to contemporary productions. Students will watch and discuss groundbreaking films by Italian directors such as Rossellini, Fellini, Antonioni, Pasolini, Wertmüller, Benigni, and others. Places Italian cinema within the context of European art cinema and film theory, and focuses on the ways these films represent and challenge Italian history, culture, and identity. It emphasizes the study of cinematic analysis and filmmaking techniques, as well as the historical and cultural situation in Italy from the 1920s to the present. Students are required to attend weekly screenings in addition to regular class meetings. Taught in English, with the option of a discussion group in Italian.

ITAL 359 A.course_name: From the Page to the Screen (and Vice-Versa)
ITAL 359 A.course_description: Examines the relationship between literature and cinema by focusing on a critical analysis of both written and film texts through a wide variety of genre and styles. Students consider classic and contemporary theories of literary criticism, film analysis, and film adaptations to address some of the course central questions and raise new ones. How does the medium affect our perception of a story? What can a film add to (or detract from) our reading experience? How does our reading experience affect our watching experience? And what happens when the book is actually written after a film?

JWST 119 FY.course_description: The history of representing the Nazi genocide against European Jews dates back to a time before World War II had even ended and prior to the terms "Holocaust" and "Shoah" being adopted as the two most common terms for naming that destruction. That history traverses multiple continents and time periods and can be found across rich and distinctive media contexts including film, television, new media (including social media, virtual reality, and artificial intelligence), literature, fine arts, as well as museums and memorials. How has our understanding of the Holocaust been shaped by those representations? To what extent, if any, should we set limits on how those events are portrayed? What are the prospects of depicting the Holocaust in a period marked by a decline in the numbers of living historical witnesses and survivors, but a proliferation of historical, literary, and artistic renderings of their experiences? Central to those questions and to this class are issues pertaining to the aesthetic, conceptual, and ethical challenges of representing the Nazi genocide against the Jews and the potential for addressing contemporary genocides through the lens of the Holocaust. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the human thought and expression areas of inquiry requirement or the artistic practice and interpretation liberal arts practice.  Noah Shenker, an Assistant Professor of Film and Media Studies and Jewish Studies, teaches and researches across areas including Holocaust and Genocide Studies; Documentary Film; and Trauma and Memory Studies. His first book, Reframing Holocaust Testimony (2015) explored how Holocaust testimonies should not be understood as raw sources, but as mediated and embodied texts shaped by the encounter between witnesses and their interviewers, as well as the institutional and technical practices marking the testimony process. His current book project, The Afterlives of Holocaust Memory, examines how archives and museums are experimenting with interactive media (which often employ artificial intelligence and virtual reality) to address a looming challenge: the passing of the Holocaust survivor generation.

JWST 119L FY.course_name: FSEM: Representations of the Holocaust Film Screening
JWST 119L FY.course_description: Required film screening for JWST 119 FY.

JWST 275 FY.course_name: FSEM: Between Promised Lands and Homelands: The Modern Jewish Experience
JWST 275 FY.course_description: What are the Jews—a religion, a race, a nation, an ethnicity or a people? To whom ought Jews be loyal—to their local community, to a state, to Jews around the world, or to all of humanity? How should Jews interact with their non-Jewish neighbors? Can Jews reconcile traditional beliefs with contemporary values? How should Jews respond to new forms of antagonism around them? Students explore some of the major historical questions and conundrums vexing the modern Jewish experience, from the era of emancipation in the 18th century to the rehabilitation of Jewish life in the United States, Europe and Israel in the aftermath of the Holocaust. Topics include expulsions and migrations, emancipation and acculturation, anti-Semitism and the Holocaust, modern Jewish nationalism movements such as Zionism, the establishment of the State of Israel, and the expansion of American Jewish communities and the reassertion of Jewish life in Europe in the aftermath of the Holocaust. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the social relations, institutions, & agents area of inquiry requirement or the confronting collective challenges liberal arts practice requirement.  Professor Daniella Doron teaches and researches modern Jewish history, the history of childhood, gender and the family, and modern Europe. Before joining Colgate University a year ago, she spent over a decade teaching modern Jewish history in Melbourne, Australia.

LATN 121 FY.course_description: A foreign language is more than just vocabulary – it’s a way of organizing and making sense of the complexity of the world. Latin is a remarkably regular and orderly language, the basics of which we will learn in this class, accordingly, in an orderly and paced way. Students gain access not just to a major language, which was, like English is today, the common language of writers, scientists, and thinkers for centuries, but students also acquire from this class key skills to succeed as a student at Colgate: you will learn to think more clearly, write more precisely, understand English and other languages to a new depth, as well as benefit your time management and study skills. Learning Latin is highly doable and a lot of fun: it might be the first time you come to really understand the words you are already speaking and the sentences you are composing! No prior knowledge of Latin is assumed. Latin is especially relevant for careers in medicine, law, politics, and creative and non-fiction writing. Completion of this course partially qualifies you for the Department of the Classics’ Extended Study courses in Italy. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the human thought and expression areas of inquiry requirement or the language study liberal arts practice requirement.   Naomi Rood is a professor in the Classics Department. Her first love is ancient Greek, but she recommends a year of Latin for all!

LATN 321 A.course_description: Focusing on the works of Livy and/or Sallust, students examine the ways in which ancient historians described and interpreted the story of Rome’s rise from small city- state to vast empire. Special attention is given to questions of reliability, style, narrative design, moral judgment, and later influence.

LGBT 221 A.course_description: Gay’s Anatomy, a play on the title of the classic 19th-century anatomy textbook, encourages students to analyze cultural conversations pertaining to the relationship between gender, sex, and the body. Through assessing the medical processes and social institutions used to regulate and perpetuate the gender binary, students gain a better understanding about queer embodiment. Readings and lectures center the lived experiences of people who do not conform to dichotomous forms of gender expression and how healthcare professionals, government officials, and others attempt to police these behaviors.

LING 222 A.course_name: The Theories and Practice of Second Language
LING 222 A.course_description: Introduces students to the history and research that has shaped the field of second language teaching methodologies. The study of this history of language teaching helps situate students' understanding of the scientific findings that have led to current pedagogical approaches. Students examine scholarly studies focused on teaching methodologies to gain a greater understanding of how scientific research has led to theoretical approaches that are applied in classroom instruction. Topics covered include theories of communicative language acquisition, current teaching methods, the definition and assessment of language proficiency, the role of social justice in language instruction, and the influence of technology on language learning and classroom practices.

MATH 310E A.course_description: In this two-week extended study, students travel to Japan to obtain mathematical research experience in a collaborative, international environment. Students meet experts in combinatorics, present work that they completed in MATH 310, and learn about how their research relates to topics at the forefront of discrete math. Research sessions are included to give students opportunities to extend their projects from MATH 310, potentially becoming publishable research. There are also several excursions that highlight Japan’s history, nature, arts, and more.

MATH 316 B.course_description: An introduction to the basic concepts of discrete and continuous probability: axioms and properties of probability, standard counting techniques, conditional probability, important random variables and their discrete and continuous distributions, expectation, variance, moment generating functions, transformations, and joint distribution functions. Additional topics may include: Markov chains and Monte Carlo methods.

MATH 417 A.course_description: A systematic study of continuous random processes through the lens of Brownian motion and the associated calculus, achieved via a balance of theory and numerics. Topics include: Gaussian processes, Brownian motion, conditional expectations, martingales, Itô’s formula, Itô processes, and stochastic differential equations. Applications to finance, physics, and computer science are illustrated.

MUSI 105 FY.course_description: Explores the artists and researchers whose contributions to music have shaped its trajectory in the 20th and 21st centuries. Students are provided a unique opportunity to engage with and respond to acoustic, electroacoustic, and digital works that have significantly impacted artistic relationships to sound as a medium. No prior musical study or background assumed. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the human thought and expression areas of inquiry requirement or the artistic practice and interpretation liberal arts practice.   Ryan Chase is an Emmy-nominated composer whose work is regularly heard on PBS and NPR affiliates. Accolades for his work include the Leonard Bernstein Fellowship from Tanglewood, the Charles Ives Fellowship from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, and multiple awards from ASCAP and BMI.

MUSI 121 A.course_description: Hip Hop emerged as a subculture of urban Black music in the 1970s and has since grown to hold sway over popular music styles throughout America (affecting genres as diverse as jazz, country, and musical theater) and the world. This course presents the history of Hip Hop over its first 50 years. Students will familiarize themselves with the major performers, DJs, and producers, as well the communities and technological advancements that propelled its evolution. Special attention will be given to women in Hip Hop, whose stories are often erased from the genre’s origins but who are currently dominating the industry. Assignments will drive students to engage with contemporary Hip Hop in their home communities as well as on the social media landscape.

MUSI 230 BX.course_description:
The 68-member student and professional orchestra offers four major concerts on the music department concert series every year. With the same wide-ranging repertoire of any major urban professional orchestra students learn about the works technically, stylistically, and historically. To earn credit, a student must take two consecutive terms. (PF)

This S/U only course may be taken for credit up to 4 times, and requires an audition.

MUSI 330 BX.course_description:
The 68-member student and professional orchestra offers four major concerts on the music department concert series every year. With the same wide-ranging repertoire of any major urban professional orchestra students learn about the works technically, stylistically, and historically. To earn credit, a student must take two consecutive terms. (PF)

This graded course may be taken for credit up to 4 times, and requires an audition. Juniors and seniors may elect to take this course S/U (pursuant to all University S/U policies).

NAST 150 A.course_name: Introduction to Native American and Indigenous Studies
NAST 150 A.course_description: What does the term “Indigenous” mean? Students examine Indigenous peoples as contemporary agents engaged in political struggle and shares Indigenous understandings of being in relationship the land. Defines colonization as an ongoing “settler colonial” project. Highlights Indigenous feminist and LGBTQIA understandings of Indigeneity and settler colonialism. Course content draws on scholarly literature, narrative history, and media.

NAST 310 A.course_description: Indigenous women and LGBTQ people are at the forefront of contemporary movements for Indigenous nation re-building (sovereignty), land defense, and intellectual and socio-political thought. Scholarly and community-based research demonstrates the nature of Indigenous women’s and LGBTQ lives in a historical and contemporary context. Through scholarship and community engagement, the importance and locations of Indigenous feminist and queer theory are defined in relation to western/colonial understandings of feminism as well as Indigenous political thought.

NAST 356E AX.course_description: This two-week extended study program based in Honolulu, Hawai'i enables students to learn about the history of Hawai'i and Pacific Islander cultures through firsthand experience. Students participate in service-learning projects, learn directly from local scholars and experts, and engage with historical and archeological sites around the island of O'ahu. Research and reflection projects allow students to expand their work from HIST/NAST 356 in light of new perspectives and experiences.

NEUR 353 A.course_description: Our everyday visual experiences typically yield a sense of certainty in that we believe we are operating directly from information in the world around us. Despite such a belief, many of our decisions and actions depend on perceptual inferences derived from our internalized representations of external information. Put another way, many of our decisions and subsequent actions are the direct result of our brains making guesses based on fabricated information. The purpose of this course is to explore how perceptual and cognitive processes act to formulate low- and high-level visual representations of the physical world, and how those representations inform (and are informed by) our knowledge of the world. The vast majority of the readings for this course employ behavioral paradigms that target the neurological (functional) underpinnings associated with visual representations and knowledge structures. Therefore, it contains a mix of both behavioral and neurophysiological components (with an emphasis on functional neuroscience).

NEUR 378 BX.course_description: Courses in specific neuroscience topics offered by various staff members. Inquiries about the topics offered any given term should be directed to the coordinator of the Neuroscience Program.

NEUR 498 A.course_description: Neuroscience majors plan and carry out one-term experimental research projects under the guidance of faculty members in the neuroscience program; such students enroll in NEUR 498 in either the fall or spring. For students who wish to be considered for honors, two-term thesis projects are required; such students enroll in NEUR 498 in the fall and NEUR 499 in the spring. On occasion, students who are not pursuing honors or high honors may complete two semesters of senior research by taking NEUR 498 in the fall and NEUR 499 in the spring. With permission, PSYC 450, when appropriate, may be substituted for 498.

NEUR 498 VP.course_description: Neuroscience majors plan and carry out one-term experimental research projects under the guidance of faculty members in the neuroscience program; such students enroll in NEUR 498 in either the fall or spring. For students who wish to be considered for honors, two-term thesis projects are required; such students enroll in NEUR 498 in the fall and NEUR 499 in the spring. On occasion, students who are not pursuing honors or high honors may complete two semesters of senior research by taking NEUR 498 in the fall and NEUR 499 in the spring. With permission, PSYC 450, when appropriate, may be substituted for 498.

NEUR 499 A.course_description: Neuroscience majors plan and carry out one-term experimental research projects under the guidance of faculty members in the neuroscience program; such students enroll in NEUR 498 in either the fall or spring. For students who wish to be considered for honors, two-term thesis projects are required; such students enroll in NEUR 498 in the fall and NEUR 499 in the spring. On occasion, students who are not pursuing honors or high honors may complete two semesters of senior research by taking NEUR 498 in the fall and NEUR 499 in the spring. With permission, PSYC 450, when appropriate, may be substituted for 498.

PCON 202 B.course_name: Practices of Peace and Conflict: Politics, Cultures, Societies
PCON 202 B.course_description: Introduces students to a range of approaches and problems in the descriptive analysis of peace and conflict. Students juxtapose core theoretical texts on war and violence from the social and human sciences with detailed ethnographic case studies. Practices of contemporary conflict are paired with the interpretive paradigms whose aim is to understand and resolve them. For example, case studies in terror are paired with the field of trauma studies; specific regional conflicts with theories of global networks; and contemporary mass violence with analysis of genocide perpetration. In the process, students are introduced to important methodological paradigms from the social sciences, chiefly from anthropology, sociology, and geography, as well as humanities-based approaches from comparative religion, literature, and language studies. Alongside PCON 201, this course is part of the two-course introduction to the Peace & Conflict Studies major and minor.

PCON 337 A.course_name: Forced Displacement: Refugees, Migrants and Asylum-Seekers
PCON 337 A.course_description: Why do people move across international borders, and where do they go? How should local communities, national governments and international institutions respond? What are the goals of policies and procedures, and how effective are they? To answer these questions, and more, students will apply a PCON lens to the interdisciplinary field of migration studies. Students will compare classic settler societies and traditional countries of emigration with newer destinations and departure points. We will also consider how the boundaries between voluntary and forced migration highlight tensions between ethical and analytical perspectives. We cannot cover every part of the world in detail, so we will also explore topics and geographies of students' choice in their Research Proposal project.

PHIL 111 D.course_description: Explores central questions of morality. What makes a good life good? What makes some actions right and others wrong? Are there human rights that everyone has? What are our obligations to others? Are there good answers to these questions, or is it all relative? Among the philosophers explored are Plato, Aristotle, Kant, Bentham, Mill, and various significant contemporary thinkers.

PHIL 111 E.course_description: Explores central questions of morality. What makes a good life good? What makes some actions right and others wrong? Are there human rights that everyone has? What are our obligations to others? Are there good answers to these questions, or is it all relative? The philosophers explored may include Plato, Aristotle, Kant, Bentham, Mill, and various significant contemporary thinkers.

PHIL 111 F.course_description: Explores central questions of morality. What makes a good life good? What makes some actions right and others wrong? Are there human rights that everyone has? What are our obligations to others? Are there good answers to these questions, or is it all relative? The philosophers explored may include Plato, Aristotle, Kant, Bentham, Mill, and various significant contemporary thinkers.

PHIL 303 A.course_description: Medieval philosophy involved the absorption and transformation of Greek and Hellenistic thought by Jewish, Christian, and Muslim thinkers, often in relations of mutual influence. The period is crucial not only for its project of reconciling reason and faith but also for philosophical insights, arguments, and formulations that have remained influential in several of the main areas of philosophy. The course focuses on questions concerning freedom of the will, the nature of moral requirements and obligation, the role of rational considerations in morality, the virtues, and ideals of human excellence. Students read figures from the three faith traditions and explore their interactions and mutual influences, as well as their differences. Coverage of Jewish, Christian, and Muslim thinkers is roughly equal, and students look at the Platonic, Neoplatonic, and Aristotelian background to their thought as well as the new directions in which they took philosophy.

PHYS 410 A.course_description: This is a required senior research experience. Under the guidance of a faculty mentor, each student works on an experimental or theoretical project that ideally produces original results. A final thesis and a formal oral presentation are essential components of the course.

POSC 150 FY.course_description: Americans have long celebrated their country’s political heritage as a pioneer in democratic politics, with the oldest written constitution still in use. Yet politics in the contemporary United States seems riven by particularly intense conflict, American governance is frequently described as dysfunctional, and American democracy itself is reputed by many to be in crisis. What connects the constitutional system and democratic culture that so many Americans revere with the discord and gridlock that so many Americans lament? And what might a more systematic, historically informed understanding of the American political process tell us about the prospects and pathways for improving it? In our analysis of American democracy, emphasis is placed on how the American political system compares with other forms of democratic government across the globe. Students also consider how the growing diversity of the American population may impact the future of American politics. Students who successfully complete this seminar can satisfy the social relations, institutions, and agents areas of inquiry requirement or the confronting collective challenges liberal arts practice requirement.   Sam Rosenfeld is an associate professor of political science whose research focuses on political parties and American political history. He is the author of The Polarizers: Postwar Architects of Our Partisan Era (2018) and, with Daniel Schlozman, The Hollow Parties: The Many Pasts and Disordered Present of American Party Politics (2024).

POSC 208 B.course_description: Offers a comparative examination of the social bases of democracy and of different forms of constitutional government and competitive politics in both advanced industrial and developing countries in regions including Europe, Asia, Latin America, and Africa. Students explore questions about the causes of democratic stability and instability across countries and the effectiveness of their democratic government in delivering goods to their citizens. Students examine key conditions that appeared conducive to producing democratic transitions across the three “waves” of democratization. Finally, students consider the process of democratic consolidations, considering topics such as civil society, civil-military relations, institutional design, and international influences.  (CO)

POSC 301 A.course_description: Popular culture plays an important role in international relations. It not only constitutes an entertainment good but also reflects and impacts world politics daily. In International Relations, popular culture inhabits both roles of subject and object. To understand these different roles popular culture occupies in world politics, students examine a variety of popular culture areas, including movies, television shows, literature, music, fashion, sports, and even museums.
